awd_titl_txt: Atomistic Mechanisms of Gold Nanoparticle Reactivity: Growth, Decomposition, Catalysis, and Ligand Exchange
awd_abstract_narration:
Christine Aikens of Kansas State University is supported by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry program in employing a variety of theoretical methods in order to investigate fundamental questions related to the atomistic mechanisms of gold and silver nanoparticle growth, decomposition, catalysis, and ligand exchange.  Density functional theory will be utilized throughout the project since it provides a good balance of accuracy with a reasonable computational cost.  Continuum solvent models such as COSMO will be used to examine how solvent polarity affects reaction energetics.  Coupled cluster calculations during the catalysis work will improve the accuracy of barrier heights and reaction energies.  We will refine parameters for ReaxFF, a classical force field, in order to apply this method to molecular dynamics simulations of large gold nanoparticle systems.

Small gold and silver nanoparticles with diameters on the order of 1-2 nanometers have a wide array of applications such as selective catalysis.  Previous theoretical studies on these nanoparticles have primarily focused on their structure and/or physical properties rather than reactivity.  In this research, the PI will examine factors that affect nanoparticle reaction mechanisms.  This research will lead to better control of size and monodispersity of gold and silver nanoparticles.  In addition, it will identify factors leading to nanoparticle toxicity.  Furthermore, this research will lead to better control of nanoparticle catalysis and assembly into arrays.   In addition, this proposal will enable the PI to continue broadening participation through the inclusion of female and minority students in research. Funding from this proposal will be used to assist undergraduate and graduate students as they perform research and disseminate their results.  These results will be broadly circulated through peer-reviewed papers and through presentations at a variety of institutions and conferences.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to learn how noble metal nanoparticles such as gold nanoparticles grow and what happens when they undergo chemical reactions.  During this project, we studied many aspects of nanoparticle growth mechanisms.  Most of the gold nanoparticle growth processes performed experimentally employ a reductive synthesis, so we primarily focused on understanding which factors lead to different intermediates and products for this synthetic method.  For example, we studied how varying the solvent in which the synthesis of the nanoparticle is performed affects the reaction energies, and thus the intermediates that are likely to be present during the reaction.  We also examined how changing the ligand on the nanoparticle affects the energetics that determine the growth.  In addition, we investigated how the reactions can occur without forming radical species.  Moreover, we studied oxidative growth processes in addition to reductive growth processes, and found that some of the S-Au-S surface units that are present on gold nanoparticles are common to both types of syntheses.

            In addition to growth mechanisms, we were also interested in understanding ligand exchange mechanisms, since replacement of one ligand by another is a way to control the properties of the nanoparticles and thus the applications for which they are useful.  In order to control the ligand exchange, it is important to understand the reaction mechanism including its energetics and its intermediates.  We investigated the ligand exchange mechanism for two of the most common gold-thiolate nanoparticles and determined that certain ligand positions are more easily substituted than others.

            Because we are interested in ligand effects, we also studied how changing the ligands (for example, from an aromatic thiolate to an aliphatic thiolate) changes the structure and the optical properties of the gold nanoparticles.  We found that there are minor effects on both the geometric structure and the optical absorption spectra.  This work also gave us insights into the origin of the optical properties of many gold nanoparticles.  In addition to traditional linear absorption spectroscopy, we also studied the origin of luminescent emission observed in these clusters in order to understand and control light emission from these species, which is a useful practical application of these systems.

            Other noble metals (including silver and copper) are also of interest for their beneficial applications on the nanoscale, so we examined these systems as well.  Silver-DNA clusters were found to be highly luminescent, so we predicted the structures of these systems and determined that they likely contain a central silver cluster that has a chiral wire-like shape.  Knowing the structures of these systems will help us understand how these highly luminescent silver-DNA clusters work.  Another study examined during this grant period involved the structure of sulfur-metal complexes on copper surfaces, which were found to have similar S-Cu-S units as those present in gold nanoparticles.

            The work performed under this grant employed calculations to predict properties and reactivity for these systems.  We developed parameters for a computationally efficient method, ReaxFF, that can be used to predict the structures and reactivity of gold-thiolate and gold-chloride systems in the future.  The Aikens group also collaborated with numerous experimental groups across the country and throughout the world, which increases the relevancy and impact of the science performed in this project.  This work was broadly disseminated via 15 regular journal articles and 2 review papers.  Furthermore, this work was presented at a variety of national and international conferences, as well as at many B.S.- and Ph.D.-granting institutions across the United States.


Last Modified: 12/23/2016
Modified by: Christine M Aikens

    Phys. Chem. Chem. Phys., 2015, 17, 7676

por.por_txt_cntn:
The goal of this project was to learn how noble metal nanoparticles such as gold nanoparticles grow and what happens when they undergo chemical reactions.  During this project, we studied many aspects of nanoparticle growth mechanisms.  Most of the gold nanoparticle growth processes performed experimentally employ a reductive synthesis, so we primarily focused on understanding which factors lead to different intermediates and products for this synthetic method.  For example, we studied how varying the solvent in which the synthesis of the nanoparticle is performed affects the reaction energies, and thus the intermediates that are likely to be present during the reaction.  We also examined how changing the ligand on the nanoparticle affects the energetics that determine the growth.  In addition, we investigated how the reactions can occur without forming radical species.  Moreover, we studied oxidative growth processes in addition to reductive growth processes, and found that some of the S-Au-S surface units that are present on gold nanoparticles are common to both types of syntheses.

            In addition to growth mechanisms, we were also interested in understanding ligand exchange mechanisms, since replacement of one ligand by another is a way to control the properties of the nanoparticles and thus the applications for which they are useful.  In order to control the ligand exchange, it is important to understand the reaction mechanism including its energetics and its intermediates.  We investigated the ligand exchange mechanism for two of the most common gold-thiolate nanoparticles and determined that certain ligand positions are more easily substituted than others.

            Because we are interested in ligand effects, we also studied how changing the ligands (for example, from an aromatic thiolate to an aliphatic thiolate) changes the structure and the optical properties of the gold nanoparticles.  We found that there are minor effects on both the geometric structure and the optical absorption spectra.  This work also gave us insights into the origin of the optical properties of many gold nanoparticles.  In addition to traditional linear absorption spectroscopy, we also studied the origin of luminescent emission observed in these clusters in order to understand and control light emission from these species, which is a useful practical application of these systems.

            Other noble metals (including silver and copper) are also of interest for their beneficial applications on the nanoscale, so we examined these systems as well.  Silver-DNA clusters were found to be highly luminescent, so we predicted the structures of these systems and determined that they likely contain a central silver cluster that has a chiral wire-like shape.  Knowing the structures of these systems will help us understand how these highly luminescent silver-DNA clusters work.  Another study examined during this grant period involved the structure of sulfur-metal complexes on copper surfaces, which were found to have similar S-Cu-S units as those present in gold nanoparticles.

            The work performed under this grant employed calculations to predict properties and reactivity for these systems.  We developed parameters for a computationally efficient method, ReaxFF, that can be used to predict the structures and reactivity of gold-thiolate and gold-chloride systems in the future.  The Aikens group also collaborated with numerous experimental groups across the country and throughout the world, which increases the relevancy and impact of the science performed in this project.  This work was broadly disseminated via 15 regular journal articles and 2 review papers.  Furthermore, this work was presented at a variety of national and international conferences, as well as at many B.S.- and Ph.D.-granting institutions across the United States.
